Name: xi xin
細辛
Biological: Asarum heterotropoides Fr. Schmidt var. mandshuricum (Maxim.) Kitag （北细辛）
Asarum sieboldi Mig var. seoulense Nakai （漢城细辛）
Other name: yan dai wo hua 烟袋锅花

Geography: throughout northeastern China, and Shaanxi, Henan, Shandong, Zhejiang, Fujian
Maladies Treated: boils in mouth and tongue (when used externally)
pain in lower back, knees and abdomen (when used in combination formula)
cough due to cold entering lungs (when used in Xiao Qing Long Tang formula)
syndrome of breasts being hard, swollen, painful; menses not flowing (when used in combination formula)
pain, itchy, running eyes (when used in combination formula)
Dosage: 0.4 to 3.75 g. Classical texts mentioned usage not to go over one qian (3.75 grams--old measurement). 0.4 ~ 3.75 克
Samples of Formulae:
For angina: xi xin (細辛), gui zhi (Cinnamon Twig), jiu bai, dang gui (Chinese Angelica Root), dan shen (Salvia Root)

For pain in lower back, knees and abdomen: xi xin (細辛), du huo (Angelica pubescens root), sang ji sheng (Mulberry Mistletoe), chuan duan (Dipsacus root), wu yao (Lindera root), dang gui (Chinese Angelica Root)

For cough due to cold entering lungs: use xiao qing long tang (Minor Bluegreen Dragon Decoction): xi xin (細辛), gan jiang (Dried Ginger), wu wei zi (Schisandra fruit), ban xia (Pinellia rhizome), ma huang (Ephedra), xing ren (Apricot kernel)

For syndrome of breasts being hard, swollen, painful; menses not flowing: xi xin (細辛), dang gui (Chinese Angelica Root), chi shao (Red Peony root), chuan qiong (Chuan xiong / Szechuan Lovage), hong hua (Safflower), bai zhi (Angelica dahurica), gua lo (Trichosanthes fruit)

For pain, itchy, running eyes: xi xin (細辛), cao jue ming (Cassia obtusifolia seed), shi jue ming (Abalone shell), yang gan (goat liver), mu zei cao (Equisetum), xia ku cao (Prunella)

治胸痺心痛: 細辛（xi xin）, 桂枝（gui zhi）, 薤白（jiu bai）, 當歸（dang gui）, 丹參（dan shen）
治腰，膝，腹部疼痛: 細辛（xi xin）, 獨活（du huo）, 桑寄生（sang ji sheng）, 川斷（chuan duan）, 烏藥（wu yao）, 當歸（dang gui）
小青龍湯, 治寒飲犯肺的咳喘: 細辛（xi xin）, 乾薑（gan jiang）, 五味子（wu wei zi）, 半夏（ban xia）, 麻黃（ma huang）, 杏仁（xing ren）
治婦人乳結疼脹，經血不行﹕ 細辛（xi xin）, 當歸（dang gui）, 赤芍（chi shao）, 川芎（chuan xiong）, 紅花（hong hua）, 白芷（bai zhi）, 瓜蔞（gua lo）
治目痛，目癢，流淚﹕ 細辛（xi xin）, 草決明（cao jue ming）, 石決明（shi jue ming）, 羊肝（yang gan）, 木賊草（mu zei cao）, 夏枯草（xia ku cao）
Contraindications:
Not to use in cases of cold sweat due to qi deficient; headache due to yin deficient and yang overactive, cough due to yin deficient and heat in lungs.

Not to use with shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit), huang qi (Astragalus root), hua shi (Talcum), or li lu (Veratrum root).

Do not use over one 3.75 g each time.

Not to use in cases of: sweating due to qixu (qi deficient) ; yinxu (yin deficient) with heat and headache, or with cough.

 It belongs to the Aristolochia family. This herb is toxic for the kidneys. It may not be legal to use in some western countries.

氣虛多汗，陰虛陽亢頭痛，陰虛肺熱咳嗽忌服。不宜與山茱萸（shan zhu yu），黃耆（huang qi），滑石（hua shi）或藜蘆（li lu）同用。每服不可過 3.75克 （舊制一錢）。
Notes:
Do not boil too long because of the evaporating oil.

因含揮發油， 不應久煎。

bei xi xin (northern xi xin): evaporating oil about 3%, main ingredients: methyl eugenol (甲基丁香油酚), a-pinene (a-蒎烯), camphene (樟腦萜), β-pinene (β-蒎烯), myrcene (月桂烯), sabinene (香松烯), limonene (寧檬烯), 1,8-cineole, p-cymene (對傘花烯), γ-terpinene (g-松油烯), terpinolene, borneol (龍腦), estragole (爱草腦), 3,5-dimethoxytoluene (3,5二甲氧基苯), safrole (黄樟醚), methyl eugenol (甲基丁香酚), asarone (细辛醚), myristicin (肉豆蔻醚), elemicin (欖香脂素), eucarvone (優葛縷酮), 2-isopropyl-5-methylanisole (2-異丙基-5-甲基茴香醚) [1][2]
potassium, sodium, magnesium, calcium, iron, manganese, copper, zinc
bei xi xin (Japan, underground portion): evaporating oil: (+-)-car-3-ene-2,5-dione ((+-)-篙-3-烯-2，5酮), 3,4,5-trimethoxytoluene (3,4,5-三甲基甲苯), 2,3,5-trimethyoxytoluene (2,3,5-三甲基甲苯), kakual, saishinone [3]
Other: terpinen-4-ol, alpha-terpineol, naphthalene, n-pentadecane, croweacin [1,2], asarylketone, l-ararinin
bornyl acetate, trimethoxyallylbenzene, I. II, III [5]

Name: cao guo
bai dou kou
cardamom
Biological: Amomum tsao-ko Crevost et Lem. (cao guo 草果)
Amomum cardamomum Linn. (bai dou kou 白豆蔻)
Amomum costatum Roxb. (dou kou 豆蔻)
Amomum compacturn Soland et Maton (Indonesian bai dou kou)

Maladies Treated: malaria (when used with chang shan to improve inhibiting malaria)
indigestion due to qi stagnation (refers to stomach qi stagnation)
vomiting (when used with bai dou kou to stop vomiting)
pain (when used with bai dou kou to relieve pain)
cold stagnation in the stomach (when used with bai dou kou to warm the stomach and getting rid of cold)
dampness (when used with sha ren or hou po or bai dou kou to rid of dampness)
spleen yang deficiency with dampness (when used with sha ren to improve spleen yang and rid of dampness)
Medical Function: a-pinene and β-pinene expel phlegm and inhibit cough.
1,8-Cineole can have calming, pain relieving, and asthma inhibiting effects.
β-pinene has strong antibiotic and anti-inflammatory effects.
Geraniol has strong antibiotic and antifungal effects; the minimum inhibitory concentration against Trichophyton mentagrophytes and Microsporum audouinii is 0.39mg/ml.
Small amounts of cao guo can stimulate the intestine; large amounts inhibit it.
Oral geraniol inhibited the activities of the digestive tract of rats.
Geraniol also has anthelmintic action against round worms in guinea pigs.
The ethanol-induced hepatotoxic effect on white rats can be counteracted by clove (ding xiang) and cardamom feeding, but the effect of clove is stronger.
Samples of Formulae:
With zhi mu (Anemarrhena asphodeloides rhizome) for malaria.
With chang shan (Dichroa febrifuga root) to improve inhibiting malaria.
With sha ren (Amomum villosum fruit) improves digestive function and spleen yang and rid of dampness.
With hou po (Magnolia officinalis bark) improves digestion and rid of dampness.
With bai dou kou (Amomum cardamomum fruit) improves getting rid of dampness, warms stomach and getting rid of cold, relieves pain, and stops vomiting.
Contraindications:
Do not use in cases of qixu (qi deficiency), Blood-deficient qixu, and when fire is high in lung and stomach with no cold dampness.
肺胃火盛及氣虛或血虛,無寒濕實邪者禁用。
From 本草蒙筌: Greatly depletes original yang, elderly, frail or deficient persons must strictly avoid it.
From 本草經疏: In malaria not due to miasma, in chest/epigastric pain due to fire not cold, in damp-heat stagnation, in dysentery or acute diarrhea due to summerheat and dampness, with thirst, in damp-heat invading spleen causing distention or scanty urination, all are not suitable for use.
From 本草備要: Avoid iron.
Roasting the herb reduces side effects.
Long-term use of smoked cao guo may cause cancer.
Research:
Half of the laboratory rats fed geraniol died. The lethal dosage is 4.9g/kg. For rabbits, the lethal injection dosage is 50mg/kg.
炒過的草果之副作用較小。大鼠口服香葉醇的半數致死量為4.8g/kg，兔靜脈注射為50mg/kg。
Cao guo which are processed by smoking can be carcinogens when taken for a long period.
Roasting the herb cuts down the side effects.
Notes:
Note: rou dou kou is another herb. It belongs to Myristicaceae.
Stomach qi stagnation: usually because of pixu (spleen deficiency), which causes weak digestion.

Chemical Ingredients.Essential oil: fruit contains 1.6%; seeds contain 2.2%; skin contains 0.38%.

Name: tao ren
Biological: Amygdalus davidiana（Carr.）C. de Vos ex Henry

Medical Function: help reverse mild liver early stage cirrhosis
Dosage: 4.5 to 9 g. Should not be broken into small pieces until dispensed.
Samples of Formulae:
tao he chen qi tang (桃核承氣湯 tao he chen qi tang),
tao ren tang (桃仁湯 tao ren tang),
shu jing huo xue tang (舒經活血湯 shu jing huo xue tang)
Contraindications:
Not to use in case of anemia or during pregnancy. Raw tao ren is toxic. Use with care in cases of xue zao, xue xu (blood deficient).
Use with care in cases of xue zao, xue xu (blood deficient).

Use with care in cases of loose stool. This herb is toxic. Do not overdose.
